Award.AwardTitle: Intrinsically-Nonlinear Broadband Nanoresonator for Ultrahighly Sensitive Sensing of Energy Transfers

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project aims to advance a new concept in micro-/nano-resonator development that involves the substitution of a geometric nonlinearity in an otherwise linear resonant system to realize an intrinsically nonlinear broadband resonator. Such a resonator has no preferential resonant frequency and is nonlinear at any oscillation amplitude and across the whole frequency spectrum. The reduced size, down to micro-/nano-scale, significantly reduces the overall system energy; this in turn makes the system sensitive to even the slightest amount of energy transfer. Advanced tools and nanomaterials will be used to fabricate the nonlinear nanoresonator, and an integrated experimental and theoretical approach will be implemented to study the nonlinear dynamics and system instability. Particular focus will be placed onto the characterization and analysis of the sensitivity of this nonlinear nanoresonator to energy transfers in hope to translate this new concept into development of ultrahigh sensitivity nano-sensors that can be operated in practical environments.

This research thus broadens the current research on nanoscale mechanical resonance, which is mostly in the linear dynamics regime, to the strongly nonlinear dynamics regime. Therefore, the research will not only provide new fundamental understanding of a scientifically highly interesting topic, but also lead to the development of a new class of nano-devices for sensing applications. The educational projects included will further broaden the impact of this project by providing appealing materials for the education of students and the public and by offering hands-on training opportunities for students, especially minority undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the past decades there has been remarkable advance in the area of mechanical resonators with micro or nano dimensions. Due to their small size these devices have unique properties and are being implemented in sensing, signal processing and high-speed switching applications. The majority of current development in this area concerns linear devices, i.e., devices where there is a linear relation between input (e.g., an applied force) and output (e.g., a measured displacement or deformation). Although linear micro/nano resonators have remarkable properties, such as high-frequency resonance and high-amplitude responses, they can operate only in a narrowband fashion; that is, their operation is confined to a single or a set of specific frequencies. This limits their operation.

 In this work we developed a new class of strongly nonlinear micnoresonators, i.e., devices where the input is nonlinearly related to the output. We achieved this by implementing intentional nonlinearities in these systems by using nano-scale attachements such as nanotubes, nanowires or nanowires. Due to their increased flexibility, these nanocompoenents possess nonlienarity due to their geometric deformation (and not necessarely due to their material composition), and can induce new nonlinear dynamical effects that provide new and unprecedented capabilities to the studied systems. These strongly nonlinear systems can operate in a broadband fashion, so their dynamical operation is nor restricted to a limited number of frequencies like in linear resonators.

To exploit these unique characteristics of nonlinear micro/nano resonators we have studied, designed, fabricated and tested several devices with intristically nonlinear behavior by integrating nanocomponents (nanowires or nanomembranes) into micro-scale flexible resonators (e.g., microcantilevers). One application that we considered was the design of a new type of Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) system with the capacity for nonlinear energy transfer between its modes. In particular we designed microcantilevers with modes that have frequency ratios close to 1:2, 1:3 and 1:5. Under tapping mode operation 'internal resonances' are realized in these systems, whereby nonlinear transfer of vibration energy from low to high frequency modes is realized. As a result, we are able to use higher harmonic components in the AFM operation, thus increasing its sensitivity and accuracy. We anticipate that the proposed approach will have significant impact in multi-harmonic AFM, since the use of higher harmonics in the measured signals can allow the more accurate determination of the topology and the material features of measured samples.

In general, our findings extend the state-of-the-art in the design of nonlinear micro/nanomechanical resonators. Our concepts and results contribute towards a new paradign of exploiting intentional strong nonlinearity in these systems, with diverse practical applications and benefits that would not be otherwise achievable with linear devices.
